CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;No violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Extradition) (Conditional) (Belarus);Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-1 - Lawful arrest or detention;Article 5-1-f - Extradition);No violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-1 - Lawful arrest or detention;Article 5-1-f - Extradition);Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Erik Møse;Khanlar Hajiyev;Linos-Alexandre Sicilianos;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE authorities instituted criminal proceedings against the applicant on charges of extortion . On DATE the applicant was found guilty of extortion and sentenced to CARDINAL years’ detention in an open detention facility .
CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant escaped from the detention facility and arrived in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the NORP authorities issued an arrest warrant against the applicant in connection with his escape , which is a criminal offence in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG for GPE ( in GPE ) opened criminal proceedings against the applicant for escape from the detention facility and for being an accomplice to an attempted murder by a group of people in DATE . This second accusation concerned LAW of LAW in conjunction with its LAW ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) . On DATE , ORG ordered his detention and issued an arrest warrant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested in GPE and remanded in police custody . On DATE , the NORP authorities confirmed that the applicant was being prosecuted in GPE and asked the NORP authorities to arrest him pending the submission of a formal extradition request .

CARDINAL . A NORP prosecutor applied to ORG of GPE seeking authorisation of the applicant ’s detention with a view to extradition . On DATE ORG granted this request and ordered the applicant ’s detention , referring to ORG and CARDINAL of LAW ( “ the CCrP ” ) and to LAW ( see paragraphs CARDINAL , DATE and DATE below ) . No limit on the duration of the applicant ’s detention was specified in the detention order . The applicant did not appeal .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG received an extradition request in respect of the applicant from the NORP authorities . It contained the following information :

“ The investigation has established that [ the applicant ] , acting with pre - meditation and in concert with PERSON . and ORG , assisted NORP in attempting to murder PERSON ... The victim remained alive ...

If extradited , [ the applicant ] would not be prosecuted or punished for any criminal offence other than those indicated in the extradition request ... He will not be subjected to torture , inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment ... The extradition request is not aimed at persecuting him for political reasons or on racial , religious or national grounds . The acts for which extradition is sought are not punishable by the death penalty ... ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG examined a request from a prosecutor and extended the term of the applicant ’s detention until DATE , with reference to the statutory DATE period contained in LAW ORG , as well as to LAW CCrP and LAW of LAW . ORG relied on the following considerations :
( i ) the applicant was being prosecuted in GPE for a particularly serious offence for which the statutory limitation period had not expired ;
( ii ) a detention order had been issued by NORP authorities ; and
( iii ) the applicant ’s detention was necessary in relation to an “ extradition check procedure ” pending in relation to the extradition request from the NORP authorities .
CARDINAL . NORP The detention order of DATE was upheld on appeal on CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued an extradition order on the charges under LAW of LAW , in the following terms :

“ [ The applicant ] has been charged under Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW , in conjunction with its LAW He has been accused of assisting , in concert with others , PERSON in committing attempted murder ... ”
Extradition on the charges under LAW was refused . The extradition order does not contain an assessment of the risk of the applicant being subjected to inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment .

CARDINAL . After the expiry of the previous detention order on DATE , on CARDINAL DATE ORG examined a request from a prosecutor and extended the applicant ’s detention until DATE . The court considered that the prosecutor ’s delay in applying for the extension did not impede the court ’s examination of the request and could not justify its dismissal .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the detention order of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , the applicant sought judicial review of the extradition order of CARDINAL DATE before ORG . Several hearings were scheduled and adjourned because the applicant sought to obtain additional evidence , lodged refugee and temporary asylum applications and subsequently brought judicial review proceedings concerning those applications ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) , or because CARDINAL of his lawyers could not attend a court hearing . ORG considered that the outcome of the above applications and proceedings were relevant to the judicial review of the extradition order and that the review proceedings before it therefore required adjournment .

CARDINAL . The applicant argued that he should not be extradited to GPE because he feared being subjected to ill - treatment and capital punishment there and because he was a follower of the PERSON movement .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG confirmed the extradition order . The court held as follows :

“ ... [ The applicant ’s ] application to the migration authority for temporary asylum does not affect the examination of the extradition order on judicial review . Such application , lodged after his arrest , should not affect the court ’s conclusions concerning the extradition order ...
As follows from the information provided by ORG , there is no information concerning any persecution in respect of [ the applicant ] in GPE for political , religious or other reasons .

As follows from LAW , the offence with which he has been charged in GPE is not punishable by the death penalty . ORG provided assurances that [ the applicant ] would not be prosecuted for any other offenses committed prior to extradition and would not be subjected to any proscribed form of ill - treatment or punishment ... ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment of DATE . The appeal court held as follows :

“ [ The applicant ’s ] arguments concerning persecution on political or religious grounds were properly examined and dismissed by the first - instance court ... Its judgment should not be set aside because the extradition order was issued before any final court decision on the refugee application ... ”

CARDINAL . The DATE period of the applicant ’s detention was set to expire on DATE . Thus , having examined a prosecutor ’s request , on DATE ORG extended the applicant ’s detention to CARDINAL DATE , the date on which the maximum statutory detention period of DATE would be reached ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The court noted that the applicant had lodged an application before the ORG ; that the ORG had indicated , under LAW , to the NORP authorities not to enforce the extradition order until further notice ; and that such indication remained in force . The court held as follows :

“ ORG ruling of CARDINAL DATE requires that detention of a person with a view to extradition should be determined under the procedure prescribed in LAW CCrP ... It provides that detention beyond DATE and until DATE may be ordered , in exceptional circumstances , in relation to an investigator ’s applications and in relation to particularly serious offences ... The present case discloses exceptional circumstances , taking into account the gravity of the charges ... ”
Apparently , the applicant did not appeal .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was released from detention on an undertaking not to leave his town of residence .

CARDINAL . As stated in a letter of DATE signed by the representative of ORG , the applicant was married to a NORP national and they were raising a child in compliance with the “ NORP standards ” . The marriage ceremony had been religious and had followed the NORP rules . As indicated in another similar letter , the applicant had joined the PERSON movement in DATE and had been actively involved in the movement as a follower and a preacher .

CARDINAL . The applicant applied for refugee status , stating that DATE he had distributed printed material in GPE about the PERSON movement and had practised and taught yoga . From DATE he had started to “ have problems ” with the NORP authorities because of his religion and related activities . He had been arrested on several occasions . In DATE he had wanted to open an educational institution in GPE , which would have taught the teachings of Bhaktivedanta Swami . In DATE he and his wife had been poisoned and his wife had been admitted to hospital . Thereafter , they had had to move to another town in GPE . Soon thereafter , a criminal case had been opened against the applicant and he had been sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment . He feared ill - treatment and the imposition of the death penalty on account of the criminal charges against him , if returned to GPE .

CARDINAL . By a final decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s refugee application . The court considered that his allegations concerning criminal prosecution in the country of origin did not disclose any risk of ill - treatment ; he had not provided any evidence concerning any previous persecution or a risk of persecution on religious grounds ; DATE and his arrest in DATE he had not sought protection in GPE on any such grounds ; his application had thus been no more than a challenge to the extradition proceedings pending in respect of him .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant applied for temporary asylum on similar grounds . His application was rejected by the migration authority on DATE . This refusal was confirmed by ORG on DATE , stating that :

“ LAW provides for capital punishment as an exceptional penalty . Such sentences are carried out . Conditions of detention are in line with generally acceptable standards ( see ORG , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE ) . ORG indicates that the charges against the applicant do not entail the death penalty as a possible sentence . The ORG has no information about torture , ill - treatment , unlawful arrest , discrimination , persecution for racial , religious or social reasons in GPE ... The applicant has not provided convincing facts in support of his fear of being a victim of religious persecution in GPE . The criminal prosecution in respect of him has no connection to his claimed religious beliefs . He would be able to lodge an appeal against the trial judgment ... ”
The applicant did not seek judicial review of the above refusals .

CARDINAL . Everyone has the right to liberty and security ( LAW ) . Detention is permissible only on the basis of a court order . The length of time for which a person may be detained prior to obtaining such an order must not exceed TIME ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . The term “ court ” is defined by LAW ( “ the CCrP ” ) of DATE as “ any court of general jurisdiction which examines a criminal case on the merits and delivers decisions provided for by LAW ” ( LAW ) . The term “ judge ” is defined by the ORG as “ an official empowered to administer justice ” ( LAW ) .
CARDINAL . A district court has the power to examine all criminal cases except for those falling within the respective jurisdictions of a justice of the peace , a regional court or ORG ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . LAW of the CCrP governs the application of preventive measures . Detention is a preventive measure applied on the basis of a court decision to a person suspected of or charged with a criminal offence punishable by DATE imprisonment when it is impossible to apply a more lenient preventive measure ( LAW ) . A court request for remand in custody is submitted by an investigator ( следователь ) with the support of the head of the investigative authority or by the police officer in charge of the inquiry ( дознаватель ) with the support of a prosecutor ( LAW ) . A request for remand in custody should be examined by a judge of a district court or a military court of a corresponding level in the presence of the person concerned ( LAW ) . Appellate courts should examine appeals lodged against judicial decisions on remand in custody within DATE ( LAW ) . The period of detention pending the investigation of a criminal case must not exceed DATE ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) but may be extended DATE by a judge of a district court or a military court of a corresponding level . Further extensions DATE may be granted with regard to persons accused of serious or particularly serious criminal offences ( LAW ) . Extensions DATE may be granted on an exceptional basis with regard to persons accused of particularly serious criminal offences ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . A preventive measure can be applied with a view to ensuring a person ’s extradition in compliance with the procedure established under LAW ) .
CARDINAL . Chapter CARDINAL of the CCrP ( Articles CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) governs the procedure to be followed in the event of extradition .

CARDINAL . A court is to review the lawfulness and validity of a decision to extradite within DATE of receipt of a request for review . The decision should be taken in open court by a panel of CARDINAL judges in the presence of a prosecutor , the person whose extradition is sought and the latter ’s legal counsel ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL lists the conditions under which extradition can not be authorised . Thus , the extradition of the following should be denied : a NORP citizen ( LAW ) or a person who was granted asylum in GPE ( LAW ) ; a person in respect of whom a conviction has become effective or criminal proceedings have been terminated in GPE in connection with the same act for which he or she has been prosecuted in the requesting ORG ( LAW ) ; a person in respect of whom criminal proceedings can not be launched or a conviction can not become effective in view of the expiry of the statute of limitations or under another valid ground in LANGUAGE law ( LAW ) ; or a person in respect of whom extradition has been blocked by a NORP court in accordance with the legislation and international treaties of GPE ( Article CARDINAL § DATE ) . Finally , extradition should be denied if the act that gave grounds for the extradition request does not constitute a criminal offence under LAW ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . In the event that a foreign national whose extradition is being sought is being prosecuted or is serving a penalty for another criminal offence in GPE , his extradition may be postponed until the prosecution is terminated , the penalty is lifted on any valid ground or the sentence is served ( LAW § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Upon receipt of a request for extradition not accompanied by an arrest warrant issued by a foreign court , ORG or his deputy is to “ take measures ” in order to decide on the preventive measure in respect of the person whose extradition is being sought . The preventive measure is to be applied in accordance with established procedure ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Upon receipt of a request for extradition accompanied by an arrest warrant issued by a foreign judicial body , a prosecutor may place the person whose extradition is being sought under house arrest or in custodial detention without prior approval of his or her decision by a court of GPE ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Verifying the compatibility of section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Law on ORG in the GPE of DATE , ORG ruled that a foreign national liable to be expelled from GPE could not be detained for CARDINAL without a court order .

CARDINAL . Assessing the compatibility of LAW of the CCrP with LAW , ORG reiterated its settled case - law to the effect that excessive or arbitrary detention , unlimited in time and without appropriate review , was incompatible with LAW in all cases , including extradition proceedings .

CARDINAL . In ORG view , the absence of specific regulation of detention matters in LAW did not create a legal lacuna incompatible with LAW . LAW ORG provided that , in executing a request for legal assistance , the requested party would apply its domestic law , which in the case of GPE was the procedure laid down in the GPE That procedure comprised , in particular , LAW ORG and the provisions in its LAW ( “ Preventive measures ” ) , which , by virtue of their general character and position in Part I of the LAW ( “ General provisions ” ) , applied to all stages and forms of criminal proceedings , including proceedings for the examination of extradition requests .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court emphasised that the guarantees of the right to liberty and personal integrity set out in LAW were fully applicable to detention with a view to extradition . Accordingly , LAW ORG did not allow the authorities to apply a custodial measure without complying with the procedure established in the ORG or in excess of the time - limits fixed in the LAW .

CARDINAL . The Prosecutor General asked ORG for official clarification of its decision no . CARDINAL-O of DATE ( see above ) , for the purpose , in particular , of elucidating the procedure for extending a person ’s detention with a view to extradition .

CARDINAL . ORG refused the request on the grounds that it was not competent to indicate specific provisions of criminal law governing the procedure and the maximum periods for holding a person in custody with a view to extradition . That matter was within the competence of the courts of general jurisdiction .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court reiterated its settled case - law to the effect that the scope of the constitutional right to liberty and personal inviolability was the same for foreign nationals and stateless persons as for NORP nationals . A foreign national or stateless person may not be detained in GPE for more than TIME without a judicial decision . That constitutional requirement served as a guarantee against excessively long detention beyond TIME , and also against arbitrary detention , in that it required a court to examine whether the arrest was lawful and justified .

CARDINAL . ORG held that LAW , read in conjunction with LAW , could not be construed as permitting the detention of an individual for DATE on the basis of a request for his or her extradition without a decision by a NORP court . A custodial measure could be applied only in accordance with the procedure established in LAW and within the time - limits fixed in the Code .

CARDINAL . ORG dismissed as inadmissible a request for a review of the constitutionality of LAW of the ORG , stating that this provision “ does not establish maximum periods for custodial detention and does not establish the reasons and procedure for choosing a preventive measure , it merely confirms a prosecutor ’s power to execute a decision already delivered by a competent judicial body of a foreign state to detain an accused . Therefore the disputed norm can not be considered to violate the constitutional rights of [ the claimant ] ... ” .

CARDINAL . In Ruling no . CARDINAL , adopted by LAW of ORG of GPE on DATE ( “ the Ruling ” ) , it was stated that , pursuant to LAW ORG , only a court could order the remand in custody of a person in respect of whom an extradition check was pending and where the authorities of the country requesting extradition had not submitted a court decision remanding him or her in custody . The judicial authorisation of remand in custody in that situation was to be carried out in accordance with LAW ORG and following a prosecutor ’s request for that person to be remanded in custody ( paragraph CARDINAL of the Ruling ) . In deciding to remand a person in custody , a court was to examine whether there were factual and legal grounds for the application of that preventive measure . If the extradition request was accompanied by a detention order of a foreign court , a prosecutor was entitled to remand the person in custody without a NORP court ’s authorisation ( LAW ORG ) for a period not exceeding DATE , and the prosecutor ’s decision could be challenged in the courts under LAW
CARDINAL . In extending a person ’s detention with a view to extradition , a court was to apply LAW
CARDINAL . When carrying out actions requested under LAW , to which GPE and GPE are parties , an official body applies its country ’s domestic laws ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Extradition for the institution of criminal proceedings can be sought with regard to a person whose acts constitute crimes under the legislation of the requesting and requested parties and which are punishable by imprisonment for DATE ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Upon receipt of a request for extradition , the requested country should immediately take measures to search for and arrest the person whose extradition is being sought , except in cases where no extradition is possible ( Article CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . NORP The person whose extradition is sought may be arrested before receipt of a request for extradition if there is a related petition . The petition must make reference to a detention order and indicate that a request for extradition will follow ( LAW ) . If the person is arrested or detained before receipt of the extradition request , the requesting country must be informed immediately ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . A person detained pending extradition pursuant to LAW must be released if the requesting country fails to submit an official request for extradition with all requisite supporting documents within DATE of the date of remand in custody ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . NORP In support of his complaint of a risk of ill - treatment , the applicant referred to a DATE report from ORG ; a DATE report of ORG ; and DATE reports by ORG on human rights in GPE .

CARDINAL . The applicant also relied on a DATE report of ORG on Arbitrary Detention and , deploring appalling conditions of detention in GPE , the DATE report on the international fact - finding mission from ORG ( “ the FIDH ” ) .

CARDINAL . Lastly , the applicant referred to ORG “ Shattering Hopes . Post - Election Crackdown in GPE ” , as well as the report entitled “ GPE . Restrictions on ORG Following the DATE LAW ” issued by the FIDH .

CARDINAL . Furthermore , as reported by ORG , in DATE ORG set up a working group to draft proposals on imposing a moratorium on the death penalty . However , GPE has continued to hand down death sentences despite international pressure . Reportedly , CARDINAL people were sentenced to death for murder in DATE and CARDINAL people were sentenced to death for murder in DATE . In DATE CARDINAL more people were sentenced to death .

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG considered the fourth periodic report of GPE , which contained information in relation to the period under review ( DATE – August CARDINAL ) . In DATE the ORG adopted , inter alia , the following conclusions ( CAT / C / BLR / CO/CARDINAL ) :

“ ... CARDINAL . The ORG is seriously concerned about numerous , consistent reports that detainees are frequently denied basic fundamental legal safeguards , including prompt access to a lawyer and medical doctor and the right to contact family members , and this pertains especially to those detainees charged under article CARDINAL of LAW . Such reports include cases raised jointly by several special procedure mandate holders , including the Special Rapporteur on torture and other cruel , inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment , and pertaining to , inter alia , PERSON who made an allegation during trial in DATE about the denial of his rights to prompt access to lawyer , to contact family and to medical treatment despite injuries caused by the authorities during arrest , and PERSON ...

CARDINAL . ORG is deeply concerned over the numerous and consistent allegations of widespread torture and ill - treatment of detainees in ORG . According to the reliable information presented to the ORG , many persons deprived of their liberty are tortured , ill - treated and threatened by law enforcement officials , especially at the moment of apprehension and during pre - trial detention . These confirm the concerns expressed by a number of international bodies , inter alia , the Special Rapporteur on torture and other cruel , inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment , ORG ( resolution CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , the ORG High Commissioner for Human Rights and ORG . While noting article CARDINAL of the LAW which prohibits torture , the ORG is concerned about the substantial gap between the legislative framework and its practical implementation ( arts . CARDINAL , DATE , DATE and DATE ) ...

CARDINAL . The ORG continues to be deeply concerned about the persistent and prevailing pattern of failure of officials to conduct prompt , impartial and full investigations into the many allegations of torture and ill - treatment and to prosecute alleged perpetrators , the lack of independent investigation and complaint mechanisms , the intimidation of the judiciary , the low level of cooperation with international monitoring bodies , which have led to serious underreporting and impunity ...

CARDINAL . While noting the information provided by ORG that the definition of torture contained in DATE Convention is used for the purpose of criminal prosecution of perpetrators of acts of tortures and ORG is preparing a bill on amendments to the criminal legislation , the ORG is concerned that such definition of torture has never been applied by domestic courts . The ORG remains concerned that the national legislation does not contain provisions defining torture and ensuring absolute prohibition of the torture . It is also concerned that articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Criminal Code do not criminalize torture in accordance with article CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL , of the LAW ( arts . CARDINAL , CARDINAL and DATE ) ... ”
The ORG ’s observations contain the following conclusions concerning conditions of detention and the death penalty in GPE :

“ CARDINAL . While welcoming efforts made by ORG to improve the living condition of detained persons ( CAT / C / BLR/CARDINAL , paras . CARDINAL ff . ) and ORG acceptance of the recommendation made in the course of the universal periodic review to that end ( A / HRC/CARDINAL/CARDINAL , para . CARDINAL ) , the ORG remains deeply concerned about continuing reports of poor conditions in places of deprivation of liberty , including an appeal by the Special Rapporteur on the question of torture concerning the conditions in several places of detention such as the GPE in GPE ( A / HRC/CARDINAL/CARDINAL/Add.CARDINAL , para . CARDINAL ) . This includes the problem of the overcrowding , poor diet and lack of access to facilities for basic hygiene and inadequate medical care ( arts . CARDINAL and DATE ) ...

CARDINAL . ORG is concerned by reports of the poor conditions of persons sentenced to death , and regarding the secrecy and arbitrariness surrounding the execution of persons sentenced to death , including reports that the families of persons sentenced to the death penalty are only informed DATE or DATE after the execution has taken place , that they are not given the opportunity for a last visit to the prisoner , that the body of the executed prisoner is not handed over to the family and the place of burial is not disclosed to them . Furthermore , the ORG is deeply concerned at reports that some death row prisoners are not provided with fundamental legal safeguards and the discrepancy between reports of the authorities and other , various sources on this matter . Although the ORG notes that a parliamentary working group continues to consider the possibility of establishing a moratorium of the death penalty , it regrets the execution of CARDINAL death row inmates whose cases were being reviewed by ORG , despite its request for interim measures ... ”
CARDINAL . NORP Some other reports and information concerning GPE have been summarised by ORG in NORP v. GPE , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW provides , in its current version , that the death penalty can be exceptionally imposed for certain particularly serious criminal offenses related to premeditated murder with aggravating circumstances .

CARDINAL . As follows from LAW , in its current version , murder is punishable by a prison term from DATE . The death penalty is enumerated in LAW among the possible sentences for certain specific situations , such as : murder committed by a group of people ; murder of CARDINAL or more people ; murder of a child , an elderly person or a pregnant woman ; murder in connection with kidnapping ; and murder committed to cover up another criminal offence .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW provides a definition of an attempted / inchoate criminal offence . Its paragraph CARDINAL specifies that “ liability for an attempted offence should be imposed under the same LAW ” . LAW provides that the death penalty should not be imposed for an attempted offence .
